text:
In Flumine, when an order changes its status, there is a very helpful log print here: <https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/0241aca36f751bf1e35c5f8d7242735d2f1a5687/flumine/order/order.py#L113> which prints out exactly what happened. I would like to capture that output in my logging.

However, when I use a `LoggingControl` to handle my logging, I am losing those updates. When I use `_process_order` it only tells me about new orders, and it does not cover status changes.

Is there a way to get those order status updates via the `LoggingControl`? If not, am I thinking about this in the wrong way?

elements.text: In Flumine, when an order changes its status, there is a very helpful log print here:

which prints out exactly what happened. I would like to capture that output in my logging.

However, when I use a
LoggingControl
to handle my logging, I am losing those updates. When I use
_process_order

it only tells me about new orders, and it does not cover status changes.

Is there a way to get those order status updates via the
LoggingControl
? If not, am I thinking about this in the wrong way?

text:
I think you might be confusing python `logging` with flumine `loggingcontrol`  however when designing flumine I decided not to make an order status update pass through loggingcontrol due to latency and race conditions.

I was worried it might slow things down but you could easily create your own order class that does do this but it does open up a few issues regarding race conditions on the status etc.

elements.text: I think you might be confusing python
logging
with flumine
loggingcontrol

however when designing flumine I decided not to make an order status update pass through loggingcontrol due to latency and race conditions.

I was worried it might slow things down but you could easily create your own order class that does do this but it does open up a few issues regarding race conditions on the status etc.

text:
OK, thanks. I'm not concerned about race conditions on the status. Latency would concern me a bit but I'm happy to give it a go.

However I'm not immediately sure how I would create an order class that would naturally get its status updates passed through the `LoggingControl` .

To do that, I think an order status update would have to be a `CURRENT_ORDERS_EVENT` and I can't immediately see how to implement that...

elements.text:
OK, thanks. I'm not concerned about race conditions on the status. Latency would concern me a bit but I'm happy to give it a go.

However I'm not immediately sure how I would create an order class that would naturally get its status updates passed through the
LoggingControl

.

To do that, I think an order status update would have to be a
CURRENT_ORDERS_EVENT
and I can't immediately see how to implement that...

text: Hmm, its a bit tricky because we don't have access to the framework from within an order. Is there any reason you can't put the data you need into the `order.context` and then log it at the end?

elements.text: Hmm, its a bit tricky because we don't have access to the framework from within an order. Is there any reason you can't put the data you need into the
order.context
and then log it at the end?

text: I suppose that could work. It would be quite messy though. I'd have to hack in the timestamp rather than letting `logging` do the work. And then, I'd have to do a lot of work post-processing the logs just to put the pieces together. If the `LoggingControl` was handling this live, it would be so much simpler and more natural.

But you could have a simple list, what would the post-processing involve?
order.context["status_updates"] = []

text:
I've implemented the blotter-comparison solution, and I think I'm coming up against the race-condition problem. I think the order changes its status before the logging-control gets a chance to write it to the file.
BUT - this would only be a problem in simulation I think?! Is that right?

text: Nah it would happen in live as well, you need to store the state in a dict or similar

text:
Not sure about that... actually, in simulation, the race condition with order status happens when using the normal logging controls, it's nothing to do with what I've added here.

When I comment out the code I've added, I still see "new" orders being written to the log with size_cancelled > 0 and size_remaining == 0.

That wouldn't happen in live trading because of the real-life latency involved.

elements.text:

That wouldn't happen in live trading because of the real-life latency involved.
